name: Procter & Gamble
title: Large-Scale Field Experiments

classification.classificationRationale: Central team built ChatPG but without formal lab branding or identity. Deployed company-wide immediately rather than through a named innovation unit. Contextual orientation: the tool is embedded in everyone's workflow; employees balance AI exploration and execution within their existing roles.

description:
Rather than creating a formal innovation lab, P&G built an internal generative AI tool called ChatPG and immediately deployed it to thousands of users — rejecting the conventional 'small pilot then scale' approach. In the first two hours after launch, the system received 8,000 requests, with company-wide launch following within 2-3 months.

The approach treats the entire company as an experimental platform. P&G partnered with Harvard Business School's Digital Data Design Institute for rigorous academic validation, running a field experiment with 776 professionals that demonstrated individuals using ChatPG achieved the same performance level as teams without AI, while teams partnered with ChatPG consistently produced the best outcomes.

P&G has since deployed three products — ChatPG, ImagePG, and AskPG — to 30,000+ users with 35+ integrated use cases. The platform enables switching between AI models 'as deemed necessary from a business perspective,' avoiding vendor lock-in. All users complete mandatory 10-minute training and an acceptable use policy.

mechanisms.name: Deploy to Thousands Before You Know What Works
mechanisms.evidence: Explicitly rejected small pilots. Deployed ChatPG to thousands immediately, receiving 8,000 requests in first two hours. Company-wide within 2-3 months. Used academic research partnership to validate at scale rather than gating on pre-deployment validation.

layers.label: Curation Review
layers.summary: Bulk curation review validated classification as Model 6b (Centralized-but-Unnamed) with Contextual orientation. Decision tree walk: no formal AI lab branding → central team with informal name (ChatPG) → 6b. Type specimen status confirmed. Added employee count and revenue. Completeness remains Medium — would benefit from identifying the central team's leader.

layers.label: Mature Platform with Academic Validation
layers.summary: 30,000+ users across three products (ChatPG, ImagePG, AskPG). 35+ use cases with internal data integration. Multi-model platform architecture avoiding vendor lock-in. Harvard field experiment validates approach.

openQuestions: What is the size of the central team that built and maintains ChatPG?
How is the academic partnership with Harvard structured? Who funded the field experiment?
What drove the decision to reject small pilots — was there a champion or was it policy?
taxonomyFeedback: P&G's approach is 'centralized build, decentralized use' — the central team is real but deliberately unnamed. This is a clean example of 6b and supports the distinction between 6a (mass adoption, top-down mandate) and 6b (central team, informal identity).
